Question_1.Context: Biodegradable films can be enhanced with the addition of metal particles, which may confer antimicrobial properties to the material.
Question_1.Question: What effect do copper particles have when added to thermoplastic corn starch films?
Question_1.A: They increase the transparency of the films
Question_1.B: They have no effect on the films
Question_1.C: They give the films a brown pigmentation and decrease their transparency
Question_1.D: They make the films completely opaque
Question_1.Source: The presence of both fillers gave composite films a brown pigmentation and decreased their transparency; these effects were more pronounced at higher particles concentrations.

Question_2.Context: The mechanical properties of materials can be altered by the addition of certain types of particles, which may act as reinforcing agents.
Question_2.Question: How do copper particles at certain concentrations affect the mechanical properties of thermoplastic corn starch films?
Question_2.A: They decrease the maximum tensile strength and increase elongation at break
Question_2.B: They act as reinforcing agents increasing the maximum tensile strength but decrease elongation at break
Question_2.C: They have no effect on the mechanical properties
Question_2.D: They increase both the maximum tensile strength and elongation at break
Question_2.Source: Copper particles at 1 and 5% acted as reinforcing agents increasing the maximum tensile strength but their presence lead to a decrease in elongation at break, affecting films ductility.

Question_3.Context: In the context of food packaging, active packaging materials may possess antimicrobial properties that can inhibit the growth of bacteria.
Question_3.Question: What is the effect of copper particles incorporated into thermoplastic corn starch films on bacteria?
Question_3.A: They promote the growth of bacteria
Question_3.B: They have no effect on bacteria
Question_3.C: They inhibit the growth of Gram-positive bacteria only
Question_3.D: They inhibit the growth of both Gram-positive and Gram-negative bacteria
Question_3.Source: Composites inhibited the growth of Gram+ and Gram- bacteria, demonstrating their antimicrobial capacity.

Question_4.Context: The distribution of particles within a polymer matrix can be evaluated using certain microscopy techniques.
Question_4.Question: Which microscopy technique was used to evaluate the distribution of copper particles within the thermoplastic corn starch matrix?
Question_4.Source: Particles distribution within TPS matrix and the presence of some pores and cracks, induced by Si-Cu particles, was evaluated by SEM.

Question_5.Context: The stability of copper particles can be modified by applying a certain type of coating.
Question_5.Question: What type of coating was applied to copper microparticles to improve their stability?
Question_5.Source: Silica coated Cu particles Silica coating was performed in order to improve Cu particles stability.

Question_6.Context: The size of particles used in composite materials can be characterized and measured using various analytical techniques.
Question_6.Question: Which technique was used to study the size distribution of copper particles in the research?
Question_6.B: Laser Diffraction Particle Size Distribution Analysis
Question_6.Source: On the other hand, particles size distribution was studied using a Horiba Partica LA-950 Laser Diffraction Particle Size Distribution Analyzer (Kyoto, Japan).

Question_7.Context: When developing materials for food packaging, it is important to consider the potential migration of components from the packaging into the food.
Question_7.Question: How was the migration of copper from the thermoplastic corn starch films to a simulant of aqueous foods tested?
Question_7.A: Using a Buck Scientific VGP 210 Atomic Absorption Spectrophotometer
Question_7.B: Through a series of biodegradation tests
Question_7.C: By measuring the weight loss of the films over time
Question_7.D: Employing a gas chromatography-mass spectrometry analysis
Question_7.Source: The released copper was determined with a Buck Scientific VGP 210 Atomic Absorption Spectrophotometer (E. Norwalk, CT, USA) by the electrothermal atomization method using pyrolytic graphite tubes.

Question_8.Context: The presence of certain elements within a material can be confirmed and quantified using specific spectroscopic techniques.
Question_8.Question: Which spectroscopic technique was employed to confirm the presence of copper in the thermoplastic corn starch films?
Question_8.Source: The released copper was determined with a Buck Scientific VGP 210 Atomic Absorption Spectrophotometer (E. Norwalk, CT, USA) by the electrothermal atomization method using pyrolytic graphite tubes.

Question_9.Context: The mechanical properties of films can be determined by subjecting the material to tensile tests, which provide information about the material's strength and ductility.
Question_9.Question: According to the standard method used in the research, what does the maximum tensile strength (σm) of a film indicate?
Question_9.A: The amount of light the film can transmit
Question_9.B: The film's resistance to microbial growth
Question_9.C: The film's resistance to a stretching force until it breaks
Question_9.D: The film's ability to return to its original shape after deformation
Question_9.Source: Ten test specimens (13 × 100 mm) were assayed for each film formulation and stress-strain curves were calculated from load-displacement data. Maximum tensile strength (σm) and elongation at break (εb) were calculated according to ASTM D882–00 standard method.

Question_10.Context: The addition of antimicrobial agents to food packaging can be an effective strategy to extend the shelf life of perishable food products by inhibiting microbial growth.
Question_10.Question: What is the primary purpose of incorporating copper particles into thermoplastic corn starch films?
Question_10.A: To increase the nutritional value of the food
Question_10.B: To enhance the color and appearance of the packaging
Question_10.C: To extend the shelf-life of perishable food products by providing antimicrobial activity
Question_10.D: To make the packaging material more flexible
Question_10.Source: The aim of this work was to obtain active films based on thermoplastic corn starch (TPS) with nude and silica-coated copper particles, which could extend the shelf-life of perishable food products.
